 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.

violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 For repeat violations, report why the previous CAPs were unsuccessful.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.

ALLEGATION:
One staff member threw water in youth's face during an altercation.
INVESTIGATION:
This complaint was received 07/16/21 and jointly investigated with the DHHS
Specialist. The complaint noted the following:
Youth A (16) is currently placed at Spectrum Juvenile Justice Services.
Supervisor 1 is a supervisor at the facility. On an unknown date last weekend,
Youth A had to be restrained. There was an argument with the staff regarding
him getting more food at dinnertime. During the restraint, someone had dug their
fingernails into his back. Youth A has healing scratch marks on his back
currently. There was a previous incident with Supervisor 1 when he was trying to
take away an extra blanket Youth A had. Supervisor 1 threw water in Youth A’s
face. Supervisor 1 is a known bully at the facility.
I interviewed Youth A at the facility on 07/22/21, jointly with the DHHS Specialist.
Youth A reported that a few weeks ago Supervisor 1 was being “petty” and would
not allow Youth A to have all of the extra blankets that he had. Youth A said that he
had five blankets and acknowledged that youth are not supposed to have that many,
but other staff don’t make an issue of it. Youth A said that he had just got his
blankets back from the laundry and Supervisor 1 took one. Youth A said that he told
Supervisor 1 he was going to get “all up in Supervisor 1’s shit.” Youth A said that
Supervisor 1 brought medication to pass and Youth A “ran up on Supervisor 1.”
Youth A said that Supervisor 1 was holding a medication cup with water and threw
the water in Youth A’s face. Youth A said he was restrained and put in his room.
Youth A denied any injuries, saw the nurse, and did not need any follow up from this
incident.
I interviewed Supervisor 1 at the facility, on 07/22/21, jointly with the DHHS
Specialist. Supervisor 1 reported that he has worked at the facility for 13 years and
this is the first time a youth made an allegation regarding him. Supervisor 1 reported
that youth blankets had been washed during shower time and kids usually have two
or three blankets. Youth A had four blankets and got upset when Supervisor 1 did
not allow him to have a fifth. Supervisor 1 said he went to get medication to pass to
4

the youth on the Pod and also had the Security Officer come to the pod since Youth
A was so upset. Supervisor 1 said that when he went to Youth A’s door, Youth A
came out swinging and the Security Officer had to intervene to escort Youth A back
to his bedroom. Supervisor 1 said that he went to the control room and did not have
any further contact with Youth A that day. Supervisor 1 said that Youth A would have
likely seen the nurse afterward. This incident reportedly occurred about a month
ago.
I interviewed the Security Officer at the facility, on 07/22/21, jointly with the DHHS
Specialist. The Security Officer reported that Supervisor 1 had called him to assist
with medication and when Youth A’s door was opened, Youth A rushed out and
swung on Supervisor 1. The Security Officer said he was able to get Youth A into a
hold, but they stumbled and went to the ground. The Security Officer said he got up
and held out a hand to assist Youth A up from the floor and Youth A went to his
room. During the debriefing of this situation later in the day, the Security Officer said
Youth A reported being angry about the blanket from earlier. No injuries were noted
by the Security Officer. The Security Officer said that Supervisor 1 did not throw
water in Youth A’s face, and he is not the kind of staff that would do that.
Youth B was interviewed on 07/22/21, and the DHHS Specialist was present. Youth
B said that he thought Youth A got restrained because of a blanket, but he did not
see what happened.
Youth C was interviewed on 07/22/21, and the DHHS Specialist was present. Youth
C reported that Youth A was upset because Supervisor 1 had taken an extra
blanket. Youth C said that he saw Supervisor 1 throw water at Youth A when
Supervisor 1 opened Youth A’s door. Youth C said he was taking a shower on the
pod and looked over. Youth C said Youth A then swung on Supervisor 1 and was
restrained by Supervisor 1 and escorted to Youth A’s bedroom. Youth C reported
that Supervisor 1 was choking Youth A, but when Youth A yelled for Supervisor 1 to
stop, he did and then exited Youth A’s room. Youth C said that he heard Youth A
had marks on his back but did not see them himself. It is notable that there were no
other reports of this occurring.
I met with the Chief Administrator on 07/22/21 at the facility. The CA reported that
she had seen the video and did not see where Supervisor 1 threw water on Youth A.
Youth D refused to be interviewed.
Youth E was interviewed on 07/22/21 and the DHHS Specialist was present. Youth
E initially said that he was in the shower and did not see what happened but then
said he heard footsteps and looked over to see Supervisor 1 throw water in Youth
A’s face. Youth E said that Youth A was then restrained and put in his room. He did
not see anything else.
5

I met with the Director on 07/27/21 at the facility. The Director reported that he
reviewed video of this incident when it occurred and did not see Supervisor 1 throw
water at Youth A.
Documentation reviewed as part of this investigation includes the following, with
applicable information outlined:
 Original incident report authored by Supervisor 1, reviewed by FM2, approved
by the Director, and dated 06/02/2021. The incident report was consistent
with Supervisor 1 and Security Officer’s interviews.
 Email from the Director noting that due to this incident occurring several
weeks prior, there is no video.
 Facility Behavior Modification policy, dated 07/23/20
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4157 Behavior management.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written policies
and procedures that describe the institution’s behavior
management system. The policies and procedures shall be
reviewed annually and updated as needed. These shall be
available to all residents, their families, and referring
agencies.
ANALYSIS: The facility is compliant with the rule. Although water could have
splashed onto Youth A when he exited his room aggressively,
as Supervisor 1 was holding the cup of water, there is
insufficient evidence to support the allegation that Supervisor 1
intentionally threw water in Youth A’s face in response to Youth
A’s behavior.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
Youth A was restrained at the facility by staff. Staff dug their nails into youth's back
resulting in scratch marks.
INVESTIGATION:
This complaint was received 07/16/21 and jointly investigated with the DHHS
Specialist. The complaint noted the following:
Youth A (16) is currently placed at Spectrum Juvenile Justice Services.
Supervisor 1 is a supervisor at the facility. On an unknown date last weekend,
Youth A had to be restrained. There was an argument with the staff regarding
him getting more food at dinnertime. During the restraint, someone had dug their
6

fingernails into his back. Youth A has healing scratch marks on his back
currently. There was a previous incident with Supervisor 1 when he was trying to
take away an extra blanket Youth A had. Supervisor 1 threw water in Youth A’s
face. Supervisor 1 is a known bully at the facility.
I interviewed Youth A at the facility on 07/22/21, jointly with the DHHS Specialist.
Youth A reported that during dinner on a recent weekend, Supervisor 1 took the
extra food from dinner and sent it back to the kitchen. Youth A said that Supervisor 1
was doing this to “mess with us.” Youth A said he was mad and went in and out of
his room and was swearing at Supervisor 1 and calling Supervisor 1 names. Youth A
said Supervisor 1 called for security to come to the pod. Youth A said that he “ran up
on Supervisor 1” who grabbed Youth A and took Youth A back to his room. Youth A
reported no injuries from this interaction and said he did see the nurse afterward.
Youth A said that Supervisor 1 was not working the Pod that day, but was in and out.
Staff 1 was the assigned staff. Youth A went on to say that the next day, when
Supervisor 1 came to his bedroom door to unlock it and let Youth A out, Youth A
was still angry from the day before so he “squared up” to fight Supervisor 1. Youth A
said that he started hitting Supervisor 1 and Supervisor 1 fell into Youth A and they
hit a wall. Youth A said that he had his shirt off during this incident. Youth A said that
Supervisor 1 grabbed Youth A and sat on his neck as Youth A was sitting by the
wall. Youth A said that the Security Officer came and escorted Youth A to his room.
Youth A said that he got marks on his back from the altercation with Supervisor 1,
but he was not sure how. Youth A said that Supervisor 1 has not worked on his pod
since this incident. Youth A reported that he told his mother about this and other
youth on his pod noticed the scratches on his back. Youth A said that he did see the
nurse afterward.
I interviewed Supervisor 1 at the facility jointly with the DHHS Specialist. Supervisor
1 reported that he has worked at the facility for 13 years and this is the first time a
youth made an allegation regarding him. Supervisor 1 reported that on the previous
Friday, around dinner time, Supervisor 1 was making rounds and went on the A/B
pod control room. He said the kitchen was bringing food to the pods and Staff 1 was
working the pod. Supervisor 1 said that he put the prepared dinner plates on the cart
for Staff 1 and she advised Supervisor 1 that there were only five youth on the pod.
Supervisor 1 sent two extra plates back to the kitchen because that’s what the
facility does if there is not enough for everyone to have extras. Supervisor 1 said that
Youth A became angry at him sending the plates back because Youth A wanted the
extra food and started banging on the control room door. Supervisor 1 said that he
tried to talk to Youth A with the Security Officer, but Youth A was still so angry and
was trying to get at Supervisor 1. The Security Officer was between Youth A and
Supervisor 1, but Youth A got around the Security Officer and was swinging at
Supervisor 1. Supervisor 1 said that the Security Officer put Youth A in a physical
management hold and then escorted him to his room. Supervisor 1 reported that
Youth A made no complaint of injury and noted that this restraint did not go to the
floor. Supervisor 1 reported that the next day, he was on Pod A and getting youth
out of their rooms after shift change. Supervisor 1 said that when he unlocked Youth
7

A’s door, Youth A came out with his fists balled up ready to fight. Supervisor 1 said
he asked Youth A what he was doing and wasn’t sure if he was playing or not. Youth
A was told to stop but didn’t and Supervisor 1 held his arm out to keep distance from
Youth A. Supervisor 1 said Youth A was swinging on him, so he grabbed Youth A to
try and put him in a restraint hold but it was difficult because Youth A was fighting
back and they fell to the floor. Supervisor 1 said that Youth A got up and Supervisor
1 was still trying to hold him, but Youth A continued to resist. Supervisor 1 said he
followed Youth A to the other side of the pod and was able to get a proper hold on
Youth A. Supervisor 1 said he was on his knees behind Youth A and holding Youth
A in a Primary Restraint Technique hold. The Security Officer came and took over
the hold and escorted Youth A to his room. Supervisor 1 said that he did not notice
scratches on Youth A and Youth A did not complain of being hurt. Supervisor 1
denied being on Youth A’s neck at any time. Supervisor 1 said he was just trying to
keep Youth A from hurting him and he assessed his restraint to be appropriate and
noted that it followed Handle with Care protocol.
I interviewed the Security Officer at the facility, on 07/22/21, jointly with the DHHS
Specialist. The Security Officer reported a consistent account of what occurred as
reported by Supervisor 1 in the first incident. The Security Officer said that when he
arrived on the pod during Supervisor 1’s restraint of Youth A in the second incident,
he observed Youth A seated on the floor and Supervisor 1 kneeling behind Youth A.
Supervisor 1 was reportedly leaning over the top of Youth A from the back and
holding Youth A’s arms in front of Youth A. The Security Officer reported that he
relieved Supervisor 1 and escorted Youth A to his room. The Security Officer stated
that he has watched the tape of this incident and said that based on what he saw,
Supervisor 1 tried to restrain Youth A and they fell to the floor. The Security Officer
said that staff 2 was there but was not assisting Supervisor 1 in the restraint.
Staff 1 was interviewed at the facility on 07/22/21, jointly with the DHHS Specialist.
Staff 1 reported that the extra plates were sent back because there wasn’t enough
for all the youth to have an extra plate. Staff 1 said Youth A was mad about this and
was at the control room yelling at Supervisor 1. Staff 1 said that when Supervisor 1
went out on the pod, Youth A swung at him and was restrained by the Security
Officer. Staff 1 saw the Security Officer put Youth A in a hold and walk him to his
room. Staff 1 said that Youth A walked without struggling. Staff 1 did not hear any
complaint of Youth A being hurt or injured. Staff 1 said the other kids were telling
Youth A that he should wait for Supervisor 1 to be alone to swing on him next time.
Staff 1 said that Supervisor 1 handles the kids well.
Youth B was interviewed, on 07/22/21, and the DHHS Specialist was present. Youth
B said that he recalled Youth A being upset over not being given extra food. Youth B
said he was seated by his door on the pod had said Youth A ended up getting
restrained by Supervisor 1, but Youth B didn’t see it because he didn’t look over at it,
noting he could get in trouble if he was looking at it. Youth B said that Youth A was
then taken into his bedroom. Youth B said that Youth D got up and looked but did
not know what he saw. Youth B said the Security Officer was there and assisted
8

also. Youth B said the next day Youth A came out of his room and fought Supervisor
1. Youth B said the lights on the pod were initially off, so it was hard to see but Youth
A had his fists up toward Supervisor 1 while Supervisor 1 was telling Youth A to
stop. Youth B said there were other staff in the control room, but they didn’t come
out. Youth B said Supervisor 1 restrained Youth A and they were “wrestling” on the
floor. The other staff came out of the control room and had the kids go back in their
rooms, and at that point, Youth B said he could not see anything else that happened.
Afterward, Youth B said that Youth A had scratches on his back and leg.
Youth C was interviewed on 07/22/21, and the DHHS Specialist was present. Youth
C reported a consistent account of the initial incident regarding the dinner extras as
reported by Youth A and Supervisor 1. The second incident was reported to have
started with Supervisor 1 unlocking Youth A’s room and Youth A swinging on
Supervisor 1 because he was still mad about the previous issue with the food. Youth
C said that he saw Supervisor 1 keep his arm up to keep Youth A back, but then
saw Supervisor 1 grab Youth A and “threw him to the ground, hit him two times in
the face, and put him in a headlock.” Youth C said Supervisor 1 was positioned
behind Youth A on the floor and had Youth A in a headlock until the Security Officer
came in to relieve him. Youth C said Youth A had scratches on his back and Youth
A’s head hit the wall.
Youth D refused to be interviewed.
Youth E was interviewed on 07/22/21 and the DHHS Specialist was present. Youth
E reported a consistent account of the initial incident regarding the dinner extras as
reported by Youth A and Supervisor 1, although Youth E reported that he was not
sure if it was Supervisor 1 or the Security Officer who restrained and escorted Youth
A. Additionally, Youth E reported that there was only one or two extra plates for
extras. Regarding the incident from the next day, Youth E reported a consistent
account of Youth A exiting his room swinging at Supervisor 1 and Supervisor 1
holding his arm out to maintain distance. Youth E said that Supervisor 1 “tackled
Youth A into the wall” and restrained Youth A in the corner. Youth E said it looked
like Supervisor 1 was holding Youth A by his neck and Supervisor 1 was on top of
Youth A. The Security Officer came and told Youth A to get up and security walked
Youth A to his room. Youth E said that he heard Youth A telling staff to stop from
inside his room and saying that he couldn’t breathe. Youth E said that he looked in
Youth A’s room and Supervisor 1 and Security Officer had Youth A on the floor on
his stomach. (It is noted that video review showed all other youth in their rooms
when Youth A was escorted into his room by the Security Officer. Supervisor 1 did
not enter the room. The Security Officer exited promptly, and the door was closed.)
Multiple attempts were made by me and the DHHS Specialist to reach Staff 2
without success.
I interviewed Staff 3 via phone jointly with the DHHS Specialist on 08/10/21. Staff 3
reported that she was working on the adjoining pod, Pod B, but was in the control
9

room when this started. Staff 3 said that she glanced over to see Supervisor 1 was
letting kids out of rooms and one of the other staff, Staff 2 or Staff 4 were supposed
to be on the pod with Supervisor 1. Staff 3 said that she told Staffs 2 and 4 to go out
and help Supervisor 1. Staff 3 said it was hard to see because the lights were off on
the pod but when she went over, she saw Supervisor 1 restraining Youth A and
noted that Supervisor 1 had Youth A pinned down over by the door. Staff 3 said that
she was supposed to be monitoring her own pod, so she helped ensure the kids on
Pod A were sent back into their rooms and then went back to her pod to let those
kids out of their rooms. Staff 3 said she was current on her restraint training and
reported that they are taught for staff to assist if another staff is struggling.
I interviewed Staff 4 via phone jointly with the DHHS Specialist on 08/12/21. Staff 4
reported that he was in the control room debriefing staff on the other pod and was
about to leave when this incident occurred. Staff 4 said Youth A was swinging on
Supervisor 1 and Supervisor 1 “defended himself within protocol.” Staff 4 said he
observed a moderate tussle that was “in compliance” from his view from the control
room. Staff 4 recalled that Supervisor 1 took Youth A to the floor “within compliance”
and “subdued” Youth A. Staff 4 said this was “clean from what he remembers.”
Security came and helped with taking over the restraint. Staff 4 said that this incident
was compliant with Handle with Care and noted he is current on his training. Staff 4
has worked at the facility for about six years. When I noted that my video review did
not find Supervisor 1 to have followed Handle with Care, Staff 4 said that Supervisor
1 was within protocol of keeping himself safe and Youth A safe and he had no
issues with how Supervisor 1 handled this situation. When the DHHS Specialist
asked Staff 4 why no staff intervened, Staff 4 advised that he was debriefing with
another staff on the other pod and that they did assist by calling security. Staff 4
noted that Supervisor 1 did not ask for assistance.
Video review of this incident shows Supervisor 1 unlock Youth A’s bedroom and
Youth A exits with fists up and bouncing around like a boxer in front of Supervisor 1.
Supervisor 1 put a hand out to keep distance and block Youth A from hitting him.
This continues for about 1 ½ minutes. Other staff are seen in the control room
behind Supervisor 1, but none come out until Supervisor 1 is fully engaged in the
restraint. Supervisor 1 initiates a restraint but is not able to get behind Youth A to put
him in an approved hold. Supervisor 1 pushes toward Youth A, with his arms
wrapped around Youth A, who backs into a wall and the two fall to the floor.
Supervisor 1 continues to struggle to get a proper hold on Youth A and the two
wrestle on the floor until Youth A is able to get up to standing. Supervisor 1 was
observed on Youth A’s back with his feet off the floor at one brief time. Then, while
upright, Supervisor 1 was observed holding Youth A in a headlock fashion and then
pushed Youth A to a closed door. At this time, Supervisor A was behind Youth A and
forces Youth A to the floor by pulling him/pushing him to the right. Supervisor A still
does not have Youth A in a proper Handle with Care hold and it has been about 15
seconds from the time the restraint was initially attempted. Supervisor 1 is observed
using his body weight to lay on Youth A’s back for a couple seconds while Youth A
was kneeling on the floor with his face down. The two get turned upright so Youth A
10

is in a seated position and Supervisor 1 is behind him. Supervisor 1 is viewed laying
overtop of Youth A’s head/neck as the two continued to struggle. Staff 2 approached
the interaction and crouched down, but did not intervene. There are parts unable to
be verified at this time due to the camera view being blocked by Staff 2. The Security
Officer arrives and engages to apparently talk to Youth A. Supervisor 1 is still
leaning over Youth A’s head/neck and holding Youth A’s arms in front of Youth A’s
body. The Security Officer engages and gets Youth A into a proper hold and they
stand up with Youth A. Supervisor 1 disengages and walks away. Security Officer
holds Youth A in the corner for a couple of seconds before escorting him to his
bedroom. Supervisor 1 was physically managing Youth A for about one minute and
37 seconds. During that time, about one minute and 28 seconds were on the floor.
Documentation reviewed as part of this investigation includes the following, with
applicable information outlined:
 Safety plan commissioned by DHHS Specialist with facility, on 07/16/21,
noting Supervisor 1 will have another staff with him at all times when he
interacts with any child in the facility.
 Employee information for Supervisor 1. No disciplinary action since 2012. No
disciplinary action related to restraint. Current on restraint training as Handle
with Care was completed 02/25/21-verbal de-escalation component, and
05/27/21-physical intervention component.
 Employee training information reviewed for Staffs 2, 4, and 5. All were up to
date on Handle with Care trainings which were received in February and
March 2021 for all three.
 Photo of Youth A’s back
 Original incident report witness statement authored by Security Officer, dated
07/11/21. The report noted the following, ‘This writer responded to a security
call to Pod A. This writer witnessed Supervisor 1 had Youth A in a PRT. This
writer took over the PRT and escorted Youth A to his room.’
 Original incident report witness statement authored by Supervisor 1, dated
07/11/21. The report provided an account of the incident that was consistent
with the video until the point Supervisor 1 engaged physically with Youth A. At
that point, the incident report noted, ‘I then attempted to use Primary Restraint
Technique to keep from getting injured by Youth A. I attempted to try and
grab Youth A’s arms and place him in a PRT position, however, due to
resident continuous punching this writer, we both fell on the floor. This writer
was able to hold on to resident arms while on the floor until the Security
Officer came and assisted this writer. The Security Officer then escorted
Youth A to his room without further incident.’
 Unusual Incident Report Summary, dated 07/11/21, authored by FM2 and
approved by the Director on 07/12/21. ‘While on Pod A in the Dayroom Youth
A came out of his room and began to physically threaten Supervisor 1 by
throwing punches at him. Youth A was still mad from the previous day when
he was not allowed to have extra food. He refused all Staff directives to cease
his assaultive behaviors and charged after Supervisor 1. Supervisor 1
attempted to physically mange Youth A and they both fell to the floor. With the
11

assistance of Security Officer, Youth A was immediately lifted from the ground
and placed in a standing primary restraint technique for one (1) minute and
thirty (30) seconds. Security Officer placed Youth A on Seclusion with the
approval of this writer (Facility Manager 2).’ ‘He has been examined by the
Facility Nurse.’
 MiSACWIS Incident Report submitted by FM1, dated 07/11/21, noted the
following, ‘While on Pod A in the Dayroom Youth A came out of his room and
began to physically threaten Supervisor 1 by throwing punches at him. Youth
A was still mad from the previous day when he was not allowed to have extra
food. He refused all Staff directives to cease his assaultive behaviors and
charged after Supervisor 1. Supervisor 1 attempted to physically mange
Youth A and they both fell to the floor. With the assistance of Security Officer,
Youth A was immediately lifted from the ground and placed in a standing
primary restraint technique for one (1) minute and thirty (30) seconds.
Security Officer placed Youth A where he was placed on Seclusion with the
approval of this writer (Facility Manager 2).’
 MiSACWIS Incident Report submitted by FM1, dated 07/10/21.
 Medical progress notes, dated 07/16/21, noted after use of Handle with Care
Youth A had a scratch on his back with no bleeding.
 Critical and Unusual Incidents policy. In summary, the policy notes that all
employees are responsible for documenting any and all critical/unusual
incidents involving residents. The documentation must be on the witness
statements and be completed by the end of the shift. The Facility Manager or
Supervisor must complete a summary documentation of the incident before
the end of the day. Incidents are reviewed for accuracy by the Supervisor,
then again by the Facility Manager, and then finally by the Director. The
Director may investigate further if appropriate.
 Handle with Care physical intervention manual for participants.
12

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4159 Resident restraint.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written policies and
procedures regarding restraint. These policies and procedures
shall be available to all residents, their families, and referring
agencies.
ANALYSIS: The facility has violated the rule as this restraint did not follow
the approved restraint model policies. The facility uses Handle
With Care and the methods used in this incident (bear hug
tackle of the youth, the manner the youth was taken to the floor
after getting up on his feet, and the way Supervisor 1 held Youth
A’s arms in front of him while bending over him from behind) are
not approved under that model. The Supervisor should have
called for staff assistance to have support prior to initiating the
restraint. The Supervisor should have disengaged when he
could not get a proper hold on the youth. Additionally, the other
staff present should have intervened to assist Supervisor 1 or
switch out with him, but they did not, until the Security Officer
arrived.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED

ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
During the course of this investigation, it was found that the incident report did not
accurately report what occurred when the video of the incident was reviewed. The
incident report also documented that the youth was seen by the nurse, but there was
no medical documentation to support that.
INVESTIGATION:
The incident reports identified above did not contain an accurate account of the
physical intervention used in this incident. Inaccuracies were observed in the witness
reports submitted by Supervisor 1 and the Security Officer, as well as the summary
report submitted by FM2. FM1 merely submitted the summary written by FM2 into
13

MiSACWIS as he was not on duty the day of the incident. None of these reports
document the bear hug tackle of Youth A by Supervisor 1 into the wall. They did not
document that the two wrestled on the floor, and that Supervisor 1 was not able to
get Youth A into a proper hold due to Youth A struggling. They did not document that
Supervisor 1 then took Youth A to the floor by intentionally pulling/pushing him
down. They did not document that Supervisor 1 was viewed leaning over Youth A’s
head/neck and holding Youth A’s arms in front of Youth A. They did not document
that Supervisor 1 never got Youth A into an approved Handle with Care hold. The
reports inaccurately state that Supervisor 1 attempted to physically mange Youth A
and they both fell to the floor. The reports indicated that with the assistance of
Security Officer, Youth A was immediately lifted from the ground and placed in a
standing primary restraint technique for one (1) minute and thirty (30) seconds. Upon
video review it was observed that Supervisor 1 was physically managing Youth A for
about one minute and 37 seconds. During that time, about one minute and 28
seconds were on the floor.
I interviewed the CEO on 08/10/21, jointly with the DHHS Specialist. We reviewed
the video and compared video to the incident reports to identify the discrepancies. I
advised the CEO that there must be consistent and accurate reporting of incidents,
even when restraints don’t go well. The CEO reported that they want to be
transparent and has expressed this need to the staff. The CEO identified that the
staff need more training on this.
I interviewed the Director on 08/10/21, jointly with the DHHS Specialist. We reviewed
the video and compared video to the incident reports to identify the discrepancies. I
advised the Director that there must be consistent and accurate reporting of
incidents, even when restraints don’t go well. The Director initially reported that he
thought the incident report captured what occurred, but later agreed, when reviewing
the video and incident reports, that they do not align. The Director reported
agreement that Supervisor 1 should have/could have done something to get the
attention of the other staff in the control room, and that the other staff could have
intervened and assisted with the restraint as well. The Director reported that they will
adjust staffing where it’s determined an issue occurs between a particular youth and
staff.
I interviewed Facility Manager 1 (FM1) at the facility on 08/10/21. FM1 reported that
he enters incidents into MiSACWIS and noted that he did enter this incident report.
FM1 reported that he did not review this incident and noted that FM2 reviewed this
incident. FM1 explained that facility manager on duty reviews video of any incidents
of physical management on the same day. If there is not an alignment, then they
review it with staff or has the supervisor meet with the staff and has the staff correct
the incident report if not accurate.
I interviewed Facility Manager 2 (FM2) via phone, jointly with the DHHS Specialist
on 08/12/21. FM2 reported that he was never on the scene of this incident but was
advised of it. FM2 said that he reviewed video and debriefed with staff and the youth
14

afterward. FM2 said that in his review of the incident that it did follow Handle with
Care. FM2 said that he felt that Supervisor 1 tried to get Youth A into hold from
behind him, but they fell to the ground. FM2 recalled that Supervisor 1 tried to get
Youth A up and did not appear to intend to go to the ground. FM2 confirmed that he
saw Supervisor 1 holding Youth A in a seated position and leaning over Youth A to
hold Youth A’s arms in front of him, and FM2 said that was in line with Handle with
Care. When asked if this was a trained method for Handle with Care, FM2 said that
they are trained that if they cannot get a youth in a Handle with Care hold, to hold
the youth safely to pass off to someone else who comes to assist. FM2 reported that
he reviewed video of this incident and agreed that what was noted on the incident
report did not fully align with the video review. FM2 said that FM1 was the manager
who entered the restraint into MiSACWIS, not him.
Documentation was reviewed from Youth A’s medical file and confirmed with the
Director. There was no nursing note documenting that Youth A was seen on
07/11/21 or 07/12/21. The nursing note assessing this youth from the restraint was
not done until 07/16/21.
I reinterviewed FM2 at the facility on 08/31/2021. When asked why the content of the
incident summary, written by FM2, which was the same as the incident report in
MiSACWIS, did not accurately report what occurred based on the video review, FM2
said that he did not write that part of the incident report. FM2 agreed that the youth
was not immediately lifted off the floor like the reports noted. FM2 said he did make
the contacts, reviewed video, and wrote the summary, but said what is in the
summary is not what he wrote. FM2 said that when he submits the summary it is
reviewed by the Director and goes to FM1 to enter in MiSACWIS. When asked why
FM2 documented on the Incident Report Summary that Youth A had been seen by
the Nurse, he said that the youth must have been or he would not have written that.
FM2 said that he does not know why there is no nursing documentation for that.
I reinterviewed FM1 at the facility on 08/31/21. When asked how and when the
content of FM2’s summary could have been changed from the time FM2 wrote it
until FM1 entered it in MiSACWIS, FM1 said that the reports are submitted on a
facility shared drive and the managers have access, along with the Director and
Assistant, who both review and edit the Incident Reports before FM1 enters them in
MiSACWIS. FM1 said that he did not change the content. He said he only entered it
as it was into MiSACWIS.
On 08/31/21, I met with the Nurse who did the 07/16/21 evaluation of Youth A. She
looked in Youth A’s file in my presence and did not find any other documentation of
a 07/11/21 evaluation. The Nurse reported that there is no time when a youth would
be seen by a nurse and documentation not be completed. The Nurse could not recall
if she worked on 07/11/21.
On 09/01/21, I spoke with the Assistant via phone. The Assistant clarified the
process for restraint incident report processing. She confirmed that involved staff
15

complete a witness report, which is submitted to the supervisor and/or the facility
manager. The supervisor or facility manager who receives the witness reports
reviews them, reviews the incident on video, and then writes an incident summary.
The facility manager then completes a MiSACWIS incident report. The summary and
MiSACWIS incident report are sent to the Director for review (documentation and
video review) and approval. The Assistant does not enter information into
MiSACWIS and only pulls the reports from the system to send to DCWL. The
Assistant reported that she does make some minor grammar edits to the summaries
but does not change any of the content. The Assistant reported that although she
has seen some videos of incidents, she does not review videos of incidents as part
of this process.
16

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4159 Resident restraint.
(3) The written policy shall include all of the following:
(a) Procedures for the review of an incident of restraint within
48 hours by a level of supervision above the staff
ordering or conducting the restraint to determine if the
requirements of the institution’s procedures were adhered
to in directing and conducting the restraint.
(c) Procedures for recording restraints as an incident report.
ANALYSIS: The facility is in violation of the rule as the incident reports,
inclusive of the original witness statements, the summary report,
and the MiSACWIS report, did not accurately report what
occurred as reviewed on video. Additionally, the facility is in
violation of the rule as the comprehensive supervisory review
process for incidents includes video review by the Facility
Managers and Director. The supervisory review should have
acknowledged and addressed the clear discrepancies in the
incident reporting and the video. Finally, the 07/11/21 incident
report noted that Youth A was seen by the nurse, but the
documentation in his medical file from the post-restraint nursing
assessment was dated 07/16/21. No explanation was able to be
provided for this discrepancy. This is another inaccuracy in the
incident reporting documentation that also was not found during
the supervisor’s comprehensive review.
It is also notable that the content of FM2’s summary, which was
used for the MiSACWIS incident report, was either inaccurately
reported by FM2 or changed by someone else prior to the
submission to MiSACWIS. It is indeterminable which is
accurate, but the facility CAP must address this as a concern,
because in either case the report was a misrepresentation of
what occurred.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
